study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fermented soybean meal (FSB), fish meal (FM), and their mixture (MFSM) on piglet gut microbiota, nutrient digestion, and host health.
results_summary: MFSM improved piglet growth and feed efficiency, increased immunoglobulin levels, and reduced inflammatory cytokines compared to FM alone. FM and MFSM enhanced carbohydrate digestibility and altered gut microbiota composition differently than FSB.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (mean weight = 8.58 ± 0.44 kg).
effective_dosage: Dietary protein level was 16%, with FM or MFSM as protein sources (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the digestion and fermentation properties of fish protein fermented by Monascus, focusing on changes in amino acids, fermentation metabolites, and gut microbiota.
results_summary: Monascus fermentation enriched free amino acids, increased glutamate content, promoted protein decomposition during digestion, reduced ammonia and indole content, and increased propionic acid during fermentation. It also altered gut microbiota composition, notably increasing Parabacteroides abundance.
population_specificity: In vitro fermentation model of human distal colon.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a salmon fish protein supplement on blood concentrations of micronutrients, focusing on vitamin D, omega-3, vitamin B12, selenium, folate, zinc, homocysteine, and mercury.
results_summary: The fish protein supplement significantly increased serum vitamin B12 and selenium concentrations, with a notable reduction in low vitamin B12 status prevalence. No significant differences were observed for other micronutrients measured.
population_specificity: 88 adults (74 included in analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of fish oil on serum fatty acids, its interaction with low-grade inflammation, and its relation to gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) in pregnant women with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: Fish oil increased serum n-3 LC-PUFA levels, which were inversely related to inflammatory markers but linked to an increased risk of GDM. The combination of fish oil and probiotics showed similar effects on fatty acid levels.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with overweight/obesity.
effective_dosage: 1.9 g DHA and 0.22 g EPA daily.
study_duration: Early to late pregnancy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) for detecting fish proteins in processed foods to protect individuals with fish allergies.
results_summary: The study identified mAb 8F5, which reacted positively with all 50 tested fish species and detected fish proteins even after prolonged heat treatment, demonstrating its potential for immunochemical detection in cooked foods.
population_specificity: Fish sensitized individuals (allergic population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish protein ingestion combined with resistance training affects neural and muscular adaptations in young adults.
results_summary: Fish protein ingestion led to significant changes in motor unit firing rates after resistance training, though no significant differences were observed in muscle mass or maximum voluntary contraction compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Young adults
effective_dosage: 5 g of fish protein (Alaska pollack protein) daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the digestible energy, metabolizable energy, and ileal digestibility of amino acids in fish protein hydrolysate (FPH) and evaluate its effects on piglet performance.
results_summary: FPH showed high digestible energy (21.12 MJ/kg) and metabolizable energy (20.28 MJ/kg), with favorable ileal digestibility for key amino acids. In piglets, 3% FPH improved nutrient digestibility and volatile fatty acid content, while 5% FPH enhanced antioxidant capacity and immunity but reduced average daily gain.
population_specificity: Piglets (initial body weight 8.10 ± 1.8 kg) and barrows (initial body weight 35.3 ± 1.8 kg and 40.0 ± 2.1 kg).
study_duration: 28 days for piglet performance study; 12 days and 7 days for energy and digestibility experiments, respectively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of a fish protein-rich diet in managing diabetes and associated complications in diabetic Wistar rats.
results_summary: The fish protein-rich diet (45% and 55%) significantly controlled serum glucose, oxidative stress, and lipid profile, improved kidney and liver function markers, and restored serum protein levels in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of food matrix and storage time on the antihypertensive and antioxidant capacity of sardine hydrolysates, as well as their bioactivity after simulated gastrointestinal digestion.
results_summary: Sugar-containing matrix improved ACE inhibitory and DPPH radical scavenging activity by up to 80% after thermal treatment and storage. Digested samples retained adequate bioactivity, supporting the potential of fish protein hydrolysates as functional food ingredients.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or model system study)
study_duration: Storage time evaluated, but exact duration not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish protein ingestion modulates neural and muscular adaptations in older adults undergoing resistance training compared to casein.
results_summary: Fish protein (APP) significantly increased lower extremity muscle mass but showed no significant difference in muscle strength compared to casein (CAS). CAS exhibited greater changes in motor unit firing patterns, suggesting fish protein preferentially induces muscular rather than neural adaptations.
population_specificity: Older adults (n=20, aged not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different pH and hydrolysis durations on the production and characteristics of fish protein hydrolysate (FPH) from parrotfish heads, focusing on yield, amino acid profile, and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study found that pH and hydrolysis duration significantly influenced FPH characteristics, with the highest yield (49.04%) and degree of hydrolysis (30.65%) achieved at pH 9 after 24 hours. The FPH exhibited high antioxidant activity (58.20%) and a rich essential amino acid profile, suggesting potential as a functional food additive.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using parrotfish heads)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of fish protein hydrolysates (FPH) as a nutritive ingredient and methods to reduce its bitterness for broader food applications.
results_summary: FPH is a good source of amino acids and bioactive peptides but is limited by bitterness. Various debittering methods can improve its sensory properties, allowing higher usage levels to enhance food nutrition.
population_specificity: Not specified (general food applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of replacing fishmeal with fish protein hydrolysate (FPH) or autolysed dried yeast on the intestinal microbiota of gilthead sea bream.
results_summary: The study found that autolysed dried yeast modulated the gut microbiota by promoting beneficial bacteria, while FPH reduced certain bacterial orders. The core microbiota remained stable across diets, but specific taxa were influenced by dietary treatments.
population_specificity: Gilthead sea bream (Sparus aurata) weighing 122.18 ± 6.22 g.
effective_dosage: 5% replacement of fishmeal with either FPH or autolysed dried yeast.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a nutritional intervention study investigating the effects of fish protein supplementation on markers of glucose metabolism and inflammation in older nursing home residents.
results_summary: The study found that fish protein supplementation decreased serum monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 and increased C-reactive protein, with no changes in glucose metabolism markers. Compliance was high, but recruitment was challenging.
population_specificity: Older nursing home residents without major cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of water-soluble fish protein from blue whiting on cholesterol metabolism in obese Zucker fa/fa rats.
results_summary: The BWW diet resulted in lower serum and liver cholesterol concentrations, including reduced HDL and LDL cholesterol, likely due to decreased hepatic cholesterol synthesis. No significant differences were observed in serum total bile acids or fecal excretions of cholesterol and bile acids between groups.
population_specificity: Male obese Zucker fa/fa rats.
effective_dosage: Water-soluble protein from blue whiting as 1/3 of total protein, with the remaining 2/3 as casein.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish protein intake, alone or combined with resistance training, on motor unit firing patterns and motor function in elderly individuals.
results_summary: Fish protein intake combined with resistance training (APP-RT) showed significant improvements in motor function (chair-stand test) and motor unit firing rates, particularly in low-recruitment threshold units, compared to placebo or fish protein alone. The adaptations in motor unit firing patterns differed between APP-RT and PLA-RT, suggesting fish protein modifies resistance training effects.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly males and females (69.2 ± 4.7 years).

study_goal: To determine the effect of fish protein isolate (FPi) on child growth (measured by HAZ and WHZ) and assess its safety and acceptability compared to a standard diet.
results_summary: Growth in children receiving FPi was similar to those on the standard diet, with no significant differences. FPi was safe, well-tolerated, and cost 20-40% less than standard animal protein sources.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-36 months in northern Lima, Peru.
effective_dosage: FPi replaced 50% of total dietary protein (12-15% of total energy intake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and suitability of fish protein hydrolysate (Amizate®) as a dietary supplement for malnourished children.
results_summary: The study found that Amizate® was well-tolerated with no adverse events reported, and routine biochemical analyses showed no abnormalities. Growth parameters were not negatively impacted, indicating safety and suitability for dietary supplementation.
population_specificity: Malnourished children aged six to eight years, classified as mildly or moderately malnourished by Gomez criteria.
effective_dosage: 3g/day or 6g/day, administered in a chocolate drink.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the performance of Atlantic salmon fed diets based on fishmeal versus hydrolyzed fish proteins, focusing on mortality, digestibility, growth, and skeletal deformities.
results_summary: Triploid salmon had lower condition factors and higher skeletal deformities than diploids, but the hydrolyzed fish protein (HFM) diet significantly reduced vertebral anomalies in triploids. Overall, skeletal deformity incidence was lower than in previous studies, possibly due to low-temperature rearing and phosphorus-rich diets.
population_specificity: Diploid and triploid Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) from start-feeding until parr-smolt transformation.
effective_dosage: High-protein, phosphorus-rich diets (56-60% protein; ~18g phosphorus kg-1 diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fish protein hydrolysate (FPH) and sucrose-sorbitol blend (SuSo) on the stability and functional properties of natural actomyosin (NAM) during freeze-thaw treatment.
results_summary: FPH-8 (8% fish protein hydrolysate) demonstrated greater thermostability and maintained protein structure better than the control or FPH-2 (2% FPH). Freeze-thawed FPH-2 and FPH-8 gels showed significantly lower expressible moisture and no cook loss, with texture properties similar to unfrozen control gels.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on protein samples)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to purify and characterize a novel β-secretase inhibitory peptide from Pacific hake enzymatic hydrolysate to explore its potential as an antidementia agent.
results_summary: The study identified a potent β-secretase inhibitory peptide (Ser-Leu-Ala-Phe-Val-Asp-Asp-Val-Leu-Asn) with an IC50 of 18.65 μM, and the dipeptide Leu-Asn showed the highest inhibitory activity (IC50 = 8.82 μM). Treatment with Leu-Asn reduced β-amyloid production in a dose-dependent manner in SH-SY5Y cells.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y cells stably transfected with the human "Swedish" amyloid precursor protein (APP) mutation APP695 (SH-SY5YAPP695swe).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-dependent effects observed in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish protein hydrolysate (Amizate) on immunological parameters (immunoglobulins, CD4/CD8 ratios) and hemoglobin levels in malnourished children.
results_summary: The study found that Amizate did not significantly alter immunological parameters (immunoglobulins, CD4/CD8 ratios) in malnourished children, and these values remained within the normal range. No significant changes in hemoglobin levels were reported.
population_specificity: Malnourished children aged 6-8 years (Grade I and II by Gomez's classification) in India (n=438).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Escherichia coli would survive extreme pH shifts during the protein recovery process from fish processing by-products.
results_summary: The study found that the greatest microbial reduction occurred at pH 12.5, with a 4.4-log reduction on nonselective media and a 6.0-log reduction on selective media. Alkaline treatments (pH 11.5 and 12.5) caused significant cell injury, except in the insoluble fraction at pH 11.5.
population_specificity: Fresh rainbow trout processing by-products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish protein substrates on nutrient digestibility and immune status in senior dogs compared to poultry by-product meal.
results_summary: Fish protein substrates (milt meal, pink salmon hydrolysate, white fish meal) showed no significant differences in nutrient digestibility or immune indices compared to the control diet, indicating they are effective substitutes with high nutritive value.
population_specificity: Senior dogs
effective_dosage: 20% inclusion in diet (milt meal, pink salmon hydrolysate, white fish meal)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish protein hydrolysates (FPH) on seed vigour in corn, soybean, and tomato, focusing on traditional and potential new vigour-associated parameters.
results_summary: FPH improved seed vigour parameters (e.g., seedling weight, height, phenolic content, antioxidant activity) in soybean and tomato but had no effect on corn. The effect was dose-dependent, with 2.5 mL/L and 5.0 mL/L showing varying degrees of efficacy.
population_specificity: Corn, soybean, and tomato seeds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a partially hydrolysed and dried pacific whiting fish product could mitigate the small intestinal damage caused by the NSAID indomethacin.
results_summary: The fish hydrolysate significantly reduced gut permeability (measured by L/R ratios) caused by indomethacin and eliminated dyspeptic symptoms in all subjects when co-administered, compared to indomethacin alone.
population_specificity: Eight human volunteers in a double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study.
effective_dosage: Not specified for the fish hydrolysate; indomethacin was administered at 50 mg three times daily for 5 days.
study_duration: 7 days of fish hydrolysate or placebo, starting 2 days prior to indomethacin administration.
interactions: Positive interaction noted with indomethacin (reduced side effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish protein hydrolysate (FPH) on growth performance and humoral immune response in large yellow croakers.
results_summary: Dietary FPH supplementation, particularly at 10% and 15%, significantly improved growth metrics (total weight gain, relative weight gain, specific growth rate) and immune parameters (lysozyme activity, serum complements, IgM) in large yellow croakers compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Large yellow croakers (Pseudosciaena crocea R.) with an initial average weight of 162.75±23.85 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological activity of fish protein hydrolysate in models of epithelial injury and repair, including its effects on cell proliferation, migration, and gastric injury reduction.
results_summary: Fish protein hydrolysate increased cell proliferation and migration by threefold at 1 mg/ml and reduced gastric injury by 59% at 25 mg/ml, with glutamine peptides and fatty acids identified as key bioactive components.
population_specificity: Rat intestinal RIE-1 cells, human colonic HT29 cells, and a rat indomethacin restraint model.
effective_dosage: 1 mg/ml for cell studies, 25 mg/ml for gastric injury model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether substituting vegetable protein for animal protein (including fish protein) in the diet affects renal hemodynamics in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that reducing animal protein intake while keeping vegetable protein constant decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF), but substituting vegetable protein for animal protein without changing total protein intake had no effect on GFR, RPF, or urinary albumin excretion.
population_specificity: 14 healthy individuals (divided into two groups of 7).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary protein composition varied but exact amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a new fish protein preparation could improve nutritional abnormalities, such as amino acid profiles and body weight, in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Fish protein supplementation increased body weight, normalized plasma amino acid profiles and ratios, and improved some anthropometric measurements, suggesting beneficial effects on nutrition-related abnormalities in hemodialysis patients. Plasma protein concentrations remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 19 hemodialysis patients (compared to 24 control subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish protein and fish oil affect the development of pancreatic preneoplastic lesions in rats compared to other protein and fat sources.
results_summary: Fish protein did not significantly alter the preneoplastic response compared to casein. Fish oil, however, significantly reduced the size and number of preneoplastic lesions compared to corn oil.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (14-day-old at study initiation, weaned at 21 days).
effective_dosage: Not specified for fish protein; 20% menhaden oil diet for fish oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of flavanol-rich cocoa consumption on metabolic syndrome (MetS) outcomes over the past decade (2013-2023).
results_summary: Cocoa-based products reduced glycemic response, blood pressure, and lipid profiles, but the optimal type and dosage of cocoa products for these effects remain unclear. The study calls for further research to justify flavanol selection and concentration.
population_specificity: Individuals with metabolic syndrome (MetS) or related conditions.
effective_dosage: 0.3-1680 mg flavanol monomers and 3.5-1270 mg procyanidins.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which cocoa flavanols improve walking performance in people with peripheral artery disease (PAD), focusing on Nrf2 activation and its effects on antioxidant capacity and mitochondrial function.
results_summary: Cocoa flavanols increased Nrf2 target antioxidants (HO-1 and NQO1), reduced muscle damage markers, and enhanced mitochondrial protein levels (UQCRC2). Epicatechin (EPI) protected against oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction in human myotubes exposed to PAD serum.
population_specificity: People with peripheral artery disease (PAD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between flavanol oligomers + polymers and anthocyanin intake with specific ischemic stroke subtypes.
results_summary: Higher habitual intakes of flavanol oligomers + polymers and anthocyanins were associated with a lower risk of ischemic stroke subtypes, including large-artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolism, and small-vessel occlusion, but not with other or undetermined etiologies.
population_specificity: 55,094 participants from the Danish Diet, Cancer, and Health Study.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of cocoa flavanols on cardiorespiratory fitness in healthy elderly individuals.
results_summary: Cocoa flavanols significantly improved peak oxygen consumption, oxygen pulse, exercise capacity, and vascular function while reducing resting blood pressure. No changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly individuals aged 55-79 years (28 female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of flavanol metabolites on glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS) in β-cells and assess whether these effects varied based on flavanol supplementation or antibiotic treatment.
results_summary: The study found high inter-individual variability in metabolite bioactivity on GSIS, with no clear treatment-level patterns. However, metabolites from some animals showed significant dose responses, and certain flavanol metabolites (native flavanols and valerolactones) approached significance for predicting enhanced GSIS.
population_specificity: Rats (specifically INS-1 832/13 β-cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of cocoa flavanol supplementation and aerobic exercise on performance, metabolic parameters, and inflammatory and lipid profiles in obese insulin-resistant rats.
results_summary: Cocoa flavanol supplementation, both alone and combined with exercise, improved physical performance, glucose intolerance, lipid profiles, and inflammatory mediators while reducing body mass gain and adipocyte area. The combined intervention showed additive benefits in glucose transporter expression in skeletal muscles.
population_specificity: Obese insulin-resistant male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary flavanols, specifically from cocoa extract, could improve hippocampal-dependent memory in older adults and whether the benefits depended on baseline diet quality or habitual flavanol intake.
results_summary: The study found that while the primary endpoint of memory improvement after 1 year was not statistically significant overall, flavanol intervention restored memory in participants with lower baseline diet quality or habitual flavanol intake. Increased flavanol biomarker levels were associated with memory improvement.
population_specificity: 3,562 older adults
effective_dosage: 500 mg of cocoa flavanols per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fish protein hydrolysate (FPH), soy protein, and casein on lipid metabolism in rats, focusing on cholesterol levels and fatty acid composition.
results_summary: FPH and soy protein similarly improved lipid metabolism, reducing plasma cholesterol and altering fatty acid composition in Zucker rats. FPH also lowered acyl-CoA:cholesterol acyltransferase activity, suggesting a different mechanism from soy protein for its hypocholesterolemic effects.
population_specificity: Wistar rats and genetically obese Zucker (fa/fa) rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flavanols could mitigate the negative impact of fat consumption on stress-induced impairments in endothelial function.
results_summary: High-flavanol cocoa attenuated impairments in endothelial function (FMD) at 30 minutes and improved FMD at 90 minutes post-stress, but did not affect cerebral oxygenation or other cardiovascular responses.
population_specificity: 23 young, healthy males and females
study_duration: Single postprandial intervention (assessed 1.5 hours post-consumption and up to 90 minutes post-stress)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether 200 mg of monomeric and oligomeric flavanols (MOFs) daily for three months could reduce albuminuria and improve endothelial function markers in patients with type 2 diabetes and microalbuminuria.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in albumin excretion rate (AER) or plasma markers of endothelial dysfunction between the MOFs and placebo groups after three months of intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with long-term type 2 diabetes and microalbuminuria (n=97, mean age 63.0 ± 9.5 years, diabetes duration 15.7 ± 8.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how dietary flavanols modulate gene expression and contribute to cardiometabolic health through nutrigenomic regulation.
results_summary: The study found that dietary flavanols modulate genes involved in endocrine function, fatty acid metabolism, and inflammation, with predicted regulators including transcription factors, miRNAs, and epigenetic factors. The review highlights the complex, multilevel action of flavanols in preserving cardiometabolic health.
population_specificity: Animal models of cardiometabolic diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether cocoa flavanols have an acute impact on blood pressure and vascular reactivity in patients with type 2 diabetes, with and without arterial hypertension.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not report results, as it appears to be a protocol for a future trial.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (with and without hypertension), non-diabetic participants with essential hypertension, and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute intake of cocoa flavanols could counteract stress-induced vascular dysfunction and improve peripheral blood flow during mental stress.
results_summary: High-flavanol cocoa attenuated stress-induced endothelial dysfunction (measured via FMD) and increased forearm blood flow both at rest and during stress, though stress-induced cardiovascular and blood pressure responses were unaffected.
population_specificity: 30 healthy men
effective_dosage: High-flavanol beverage (150 mg (-)-epicatechin) vs. low-flavanol beverage (<4 mg (-)-epicatechin), consumed once 1.5 hours before stress task

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cocoa flavanols could improve memory function in healthy aging adults, particularly targeting hippocampal-dependent cognitive tasks.
results_summary: Flavanols improved hippocampal-dependent list-learning performance, especially in participants with poorer baseline diet quality, but did not affect object-recognition or list-sorting tasks. Imaging suggested flavanols may target the dentate gyrus.
population_specificity: 211 healthy adults aged 50-75 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether microbial metabolites of flavanols, rather than native flavanols, are responsible for chemopreventive effects against bladder cancer proliferation.
results_summary: The study found that microbial metabolites (valerolactones, phenylalkyl acids, and hippuric acids) were positively associated with reduced bladder cancer proliferation in vitro, while native flavanols showed poor correlation with activity. This suggests that microbial metabolites may drive the chemopreventive effects of flavanol consumption in uroepithelial cells.
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo) and four bladder cancer cell models (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cocoa flavanols alter brain excitability in young healthy adults, both acutely and after short-term chronic ingestion.
results_summary: The study found no robust alteration in corticospinal or intracortical excitability following acute or chronic ingestion of cocoa flavanols, suggesting they may primarily affect cerebral endothelial function rather than brain excitability in this population.
population_specificity: Young healthy adults
effective_dosage: High dose (695 mg flavanols, 150 mg (-)-epicatechin) and low dose (5 mg flavanols, 0 mg (-)-epicatechin), ingested once daily for the chronic intervention.
study_duration: Acute (1-2 hours post-ingestion) and chronic (5 consecutive days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically investigate the molecular mechanisms of flavanols, focusing on gene regulation in cell types relevant to cardiometabolic disease.
results_summary: The study identified 54 differentially expressed genes in response to flavanols, primarily involved in inflammation, leukocyte adhesion, lipid metabolism, and anti-inflammatory responses. Potential transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulators, such as GATA2, NFKB1, and specific miRNAs, were also identified.
population_specificity: In vitro models of cardiometabolic disease (hepatocytes, adipocytes, endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, and immune cells).
effective_dosage: Low concentrations close to plasma levels (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the specific compounds in grape seed proanthocyanidin extract (GSPE) responsible for modulating enterohormone secretion and to evaluate their effects in human and pig gastrointestinal systems.
results_summary: The study found that GSPE and its pure compounds (procyanidin dimer B2 and catechin monomers) differentially stimulated the release of enterohormones (PYY and CCK) in specific intestinal segments, suggesting they act through apically located chemosensors unevenly distributed along the gastrointestinal tract.
population_specificity: Human colon and pig ex vivo intestinal systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether monomeric (epi)catechins (EPC) or oligomeric procyanidins (OPCs) contribute more to the bioavailable pool of hydroxyphenyl-γ-valerolactones (HGVLs) derived from flavanols.
results_summary: The study found that monomeric catechins are efficiently converted to HGVLs and excreted in urine, while oligomeric procyanidins show limited conversion. The high-dose EPC group had a tenfold higher urinary excretion of HGVLs compared to the OPC group.
population_specificity: Participants in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover trial (specific demographics not provided).
effective_dosage: i) 70 mg EPC + 65 mg OPC, ii) 140 mg EPC + 130 mg OPC, iii) 6 mg EPC + 130 mg OPC, iv) placebo; administered once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily supplementation of 200 mg monomeric and oligomeric flavanols (MOF) improves renal endothelial function in patients with type 2 diabetes and microalbuminuria.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that MOF supplementation would reduce albumin excretion rate (AER) and improve endothelial biomarkers, but the abstract does not report specific results, only the study design and endpoints.
population_specificity: Patients aged 40-85 with type 2 diabetes and microalbuminuria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the dose-response relationship between cocoa flavanols and endothelial function, measured by flow-mediated dilation (FMD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant improvement in FMD by 1.17% with cocoa flavanols, showing a non-linear (inverted U-shape) association. The optimal effect was observed with 710 mg total flavanols, 95 mg (-)-epicatechin, or 25 mg (+)-catechin, though substantial variation and risk-of-bias concerns were noted.
population_specificity: Human participants in intervention studies (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 80 to 1248 mg (mean: 704 mg) more flavanols than control groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which ECG, EGCG, and Procyanidin delay starch digestion through interactions with α-amylase and starch.
results_summary: The study found that ECG, EGCG, and Procyanidin inhibit α-amylase activity, with ECG and Procyanidin showing mixed inhibition and EGCG showing non-competitive inhibition. Additionally, flavanols bind with starch, further inhibiting its digestion, suggesting potential as an adjuvant therapy for diabetes.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: IC50 values: ECG (172.21 ± 0.22 μg/mL), EGCG (732.15 ± 0.13 μg/mL), Procyanidin (504.45 ± 0.19 μg/mL)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel naturally occurring α-glucosidase and lipase inhibitors from pu-erh tea, focusing on flavanols, to explore their potential in treating hyperglycaemia and dyslipidemia.
results_summary: The study isolated a new flavanol and 16 known analogs, with compound 15 showing significant inhibitory effects against maltase (IC50 1.3 μmol/L) and moderate effects against sucrase (IC50 32.5 μmol/L). Several compounds (8, 10, 11, 15) also exhibited moderate lipase inhibitory activity (IC50 13.3–19.8 μmol/L).
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 values provided for in vitro activity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of flavanols and other flavonoid subclasses on obesity-related anthropometric measures, such as BMI, waist circumference, and body fat percentage.
results_summary: Flavanols showed potential for decreasing BMI, particularly in Asians, individuals under 50, those with BMI ≥ 25 kg/m², and at doses ≥ 500 mg/day. They also reduced waist circumference but had no significant effect on body fat percentage.
population_specificity: Overall population, with subgroup analyses for Asians, non-Asians, ages < 50, and individuals with BMI ≥ 25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of flavanols and their derivatives on acrylamide formation in a potato-based model system under low-moisture conditions.
results_summary: Flavanols and derivatives (100μmol/L) suppressed acrylamide formation by 59.9-78.2%, while higher concentrations (10,000μmol/L) promoted acrylamide formation by 2.15-2.84-fold. The study found strong correlations between inhibition rates and antioxidant capacity changes, with the SVR model providing robust predictive performance.
population_specificity: Potato-based equimolar asparagine-reducing sugar model system (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cocoa powder, cocoa extract, and their main flavanols on plasma biomarkers related to impaired coagulation and fibrinolysis, and their association with hypertension and obesity-related metabolic disorders in rats fed a hypercaloric diet.
results_summary: Cocoa powder, cocoa extract, and their main flavanols significantly decreased plasma biomarkers related to impaired coagulation and fibrinolysis, reduced blood pressure, oxidative stress, and improved dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and inflammation markers in rats fed a hypercaloric diet.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a hypercaloric diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic potential of high-dose cocoa flavanols in improving cardiac function in patients with chronic heart failure by measuring reductions in NT-proBNP.
results_summary: High-flavanol dark chocolate (HFDC) significantly reduced NT-proBNP levels and diastolic blood pressure compared to low-flavanol dark chocolate (LFDC), suggesting improved cardiac function and reduced vascular resistance.
population_specificity: Thirty-two patients with chronic heart failure, stable on guideline-directed medical therapy.
effective_dosage: 1064 mg of flavanols/day (via 50 g/day of high-flavanol dark chocolate).
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention (with crossover for an additional 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the short- and long-term effects of grape-seed phenolic extract (GSPE) on ghrelin secretion and its role in satiety, focusing on the contributions of monomeric flavanols, oligomeric flavanols, and gallic acid.
results_summary: GSPE initially increased ghrelin secretion but led to a long-term decrease in ghrelin expression, contributing to sustained satiety. Monomeric flavanols stimulated ghrelin release via bitter taste receptors, while gallic acid and oligomeric flavanols inhibited it.
population_specificity: Rats and a mouse ghrelinoma cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of cocoa flavanols on endothelial function and markers of metabolic syndrome, including blood pressure and insulin sensitivity.
results_summary: Cocoa flavanols significantly improved endothelial function and key metabolic markers, with dark chocolate being 8 times more effective than cocoa powder drinks for blood pressure reduction. However, the high energy content of flavanol-rich foods raises concerns about excessive fat and sugar intake.
population_specificity: Not specified (general metabolic syndrome population implied).
effective_dosage: Not specified (equivalent flavanol doses compared between dark chocolate and cocoa powder drinks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of cocoa products and flavanols on platelet aggregation in human intervention studies.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa products in bolus administration positively affected platelet aggregation in healthy subjects and diseased patients, but the effect varied based on the platelet aggregation test used. Long-term effects and bioactive components involved remain unclear.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and diseased patients.
study_duration: Varied, with only five interventions involving repeated administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-flavanol diet could improve dentate gyrus (DG) function and associated memory decline in healthy aging adults.
results_summary: The study found that a high-flavanol diet enhanced DG function, as measured by fMRI and cognitive testing, suggesting it may ameliorate age-related cognitive decline.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 50-69 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high vs. low cocoa flavanol-containing diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study interactions between cocoa flavanols and nitrate, focusing on absorption, bioavailability, excretion, and efficacy in improving endothelial function.
results_summary: Both cocoa flavanols and nitrate intake-dependent improved endothelial function, with additive effects at low intake levels. Cocoa flavanols enhanced nitrate-related gastric NO formation but attenuated plasma nitrite increases after nitrate intake.
population_specificity: 15 healthy subjects
effective_dosage: Cocoa flavanols (1.4-10.9 mg/kg bw), nitrate (0.1-10 mg/kg bw)
study_duration: Measurements taken up to 4 hours post-ingestion
interactions: Cocoa flavanols enhanced nitrate-related gastric NO formation but attenuated plasma nitrite increases after nitrate intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of monomeric and oligomeric flavanols (MOF) from grape seeds on gene expression profiles in leukocytes and assess changes in DNA methylation.
results_summary: MOF supplementation modulated the expression of 864 genes involved in immune cell adhesion and NF-κB activity, suggesting cardiovascular benefits, but no significant changes in DNA methylation were observed due to high inter-individual variability.
population_specificity: Male smokers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate flavanol intake and identify their main dietary sources among people in Germany to assess potential health benefits.
results_summary: The study found that mean flavanol intake in Germany was 386 mg/day, with variations by age and sex. Pome fruits and black tea were the primary sources, contributing 27% and 25% of total flavanols, respectively.
population_specificity: 15,371 individuals aged 14-80 years living in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neuromodulatory and neuroprotective effects of cocoa flavanols in humans, focusing on their potential benefits for neurocognition and behavior.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa flavanols accumulate in brain regions involved in learning and memory, promoting neurogenesis, neuronal function, and brain connectivity. Long-term consumption showed protective effects against cognitive decline in animal models, with some human studies corroborating these findings, though immediate effects remain inconclusive.
population_specificity: Humans and animal models (normal aging, dementia, and stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different carbohydrate types (maltitol vs. sucrose) in chocolate affect flavanol absorption and metabolism.
results_summary: Total flavanol absorption was lower with maltitol-containing chocolate compared to sucrose-containing chocolate, though the O-methylation pattern remained unchanged. Individual levels of certain flavanol metabolites were also reduced with maltitol.
population_specificity: Fifteen volunteers in a randomized, double-blind, three-arm cross-over study.
effective_dosage: High-flavanol chocolates (266 mg with maltitol, 251 mg with sucrose) and low-flavanol chocolate (48 mg with sucrose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether procyanidins contribute to the systemic pool of flavanols in humans, which could affect cardiovascular benefits.
results_summary: The study found that dietary procyanidins do not significantly contribute to systemic flavanol levels, rejecting the idea that their breakdown into flavanols affects vascular function. Only flavanol-containing drinks led to measurable circulating flavanol concentrations.
population_specificity: 12 human subjects
effective_dosage: Not specified (test drinks with flavanols, procyanidins, or both)
study_duration: Not specified (postprandial plasma and urine analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular health benefits of monomeric and oligomeric flavanols (MOF) from grape seeds, focusing on their effects on vascular function, lipid metabolism, redox balance, and inflammation.
results_summary: MOF supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol and LDL in volunteers with elevated baseline levels, improved glutathione balance, and exerted anti-inflammatory effects, though no significant changes were observed in vascular function or other biomarkers. A global vascular health index showed overall improvement.
population_specificity: 28 male smokers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticarcinogenic effects of flavanols (EC, ECG, and PB2) on colon cancer cell lines (Caco-2 and SW480).
results_summary: ECG showed strong growth inhibition and induced apoptosis in SW480 cells but had no effect on Caco-2 cells, while PB2 promoted cell growth in SW480 cells and had no effect on Caco-2 cells. EC had no significant effects on either cell line.
population_specificity: Colon cancer cell lines (Caco-2 and SW480).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between nuclear flavanol patterns and cell lineage development in Tsuga canadensis (hemlock), focusing on epigenetic modulation and environmental influences.
results_summary: The study found that nuclear flavanol patterns are uniform within cell lineages but vary between lineages, indicating epigenetic positional signals. Drought drastically reduced nuclear flavanols, but sucrose or cytokinin treatment restored them. Flavanols were significantly higher in anthers during meiosis compared to newly sprouting needles.
population_specificity: Needle primordia and anthers of Tsuga canadensis (hemlock)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant response of colon-derived Caco2 cells to dietary flavanols, focusing on their ability to reduce oxidative stress and cellular death.
results_summary: Flavanols decreased ROS production and prevented caspase-3 activation, with PB2 notably enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity and improving cell viability under oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Colon-derived Caco2 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prebiotic potential of cocoa flavanols by examining their effects on gut microbiota and related biochemical markers in healthy humans.
results_summary: The study found that high-cocoa flavanol intake significantly increased beneficial bifidobacterial and lactobacilli populations while reducing clostridia counts, alongside lowering plasma triacylglycerol and C-reactive protein concentrations. These changes suggest prebiotic benefits from flavanol-rich foods.
population_specificity: Twenty-two healthy human volunteers
effective_dosage: 494 mg cocoa flavanols/day (high-cocoa group) and 23 mg/day (low-cocoa group)
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention arm, with a 4-week washout period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key questions and gaps in understanding the role of dietary flavanols and procyanidins in preventing or treating cardiovascular diseases.
results_summary: The abstract highlights significant progress in flavanol analytics and epidemiological data but notes a lack of comprehensive understanding of their pharmacological properties and mechanisms of action in vivo. A conclusive causal relationship between flavanol intake and cardiovascular health benefits remains unestablished.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of flavanols and cardiovascular health)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential cardiovascular benefits of flavanols, focusing on their effects on vascular health and nitric oxide bioactivity.
results_summary: The study found that flavanols may improve endothelium-dependent vasodilation, blood pressure, platelet function, and glucose tolerance, but long-term effects and precise biological targets remain unclear.
population_specificity: Healthy humans and those with increased cardiovascular risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular benefits of flavanol-containing cocoa products, specifically their effects on endothelial function, platelet function, and blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found that daily consumption of flavanol-containing dark chocolate significantly reduced systolic blood pressure by 5.8 mmHg and improved endothelial and platelet function, supporting potential cardiovascular benefits.
population_specificity: Normotensive individuals with mild hypercholesterolemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cocoa flavanols, alone or combined with exercise, improve cardiometabolic function and body composition in obese individuals.
results_summary: High-flavanol cocoa (HF) improved endothelial function (acute and chronic increases in FMD), reduced insulin resistance, and lowered blood pressure, but did not enhance exercise-induced fat loss or metabolism. Exercise independently increased fat oxidation and reduced abdominal fat.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (BMI=33.5 kg/m², n=49).
effective_dosage: 902 mg flavanols (HF) or 36 mg flavanols (LF) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 1-month dietary intervention with flavanol-containing cocoa improves endothelial dysfunction and enhances the number and function of circulating angiogenic cells (CACs) in coronary artery disease (CAD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that high-flavanol intake (HiFI) improved endothelium-dependent vasomotor function by 47%, increased the number of CD34+/KDR+-CACs by 2.2-fold, reduced systolic blood pressure by 4.2 mm Hg, and increased plasma nitrite levels by 74 nM compared to low-flavanol intake (LoFI). CAC functions (survival, differentiation, proliferation, migration) were unchanged.
population_specificity: 16 CAD patients (mean age 64±3 years) medically managed according to current guidelines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flavanol consumption increases circulating NO levels by reducing arginase activity in endothelial cells, kidneys, and erythrocytes.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa flavanols reduced arginase-2 mRNA expression and activity in endothelial cells, decreased kidney arginase activity in rats, and lowered erythrocyte arginase activity in healthy humans.
population_specificity: Human endothelial cells (HUVEC), rats, and healthy human participants.
effective_dosage: Not specified (referred to as "high flavanol beverage").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential anti-inflammatory effects of cocoa-derived flavanols on cardiovascular health and their relevance to chronic diseases linked to inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that cocoa-derived flavanols may reduce pro-inflammatory mediators and signaling pathways in model systems, but evidence is primarily from in vitro experiments, necessitating further human clinical trials for confirmation.
population_specificity: Not specified (model systems, primarily in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Port wine (containing flavanols and ethanol) could prevent ethanol-induced lipofuscin formation in neurons, compared to ethanol supplemented with flavanols alone.
results_summary: Port wine did not prevent ethanol-induced lipofuscin formation in neurons, unlike ethanol supplemented with flavanols. The reduced antioxidant effect of Port wine may be due to differences in flavanol type, amount, or sugar content.
population_specificity: Six-month-old rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how macronutrient-rich foods and Famotidine affect the absorption and metabolism of flavanols from cocoa.
results_summary: Carbohydrate-rich meals (sugar and bread) significantly increased flavanol absorption (AUC to 140% of control), while lipid/protein-rich meals and Famotidine had minimal effects. Plasma antioxidant capacity also showed a tendency to increase with cocoa treatment.
population_specificity: 6 subjects per crossover intervention (total of 4 studies).
effective_dosage: 0.125 g/kg body weight of sugar-free, flavanol-rich cocoa.
study_duration: Not specified (blood samples taken at 5 time points including baseline).
interactions: Carbohydrate-rich meals increased flavanol absorption; Famotidine had minimal effect.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 28 days of cocoa flavanol and procyanidin supplementation could modulate platelet reactivity, reduce oxidative markers, and improve primary hemostasis in healthy humans.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation significantly increased plasma epicatechin and catechin concentrations, reduced platelet activation and aggregation, and increased plasma ascorbic acid levels, though oxidative markers and antioxidant status remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 32 healthy subjects
effective_dosage: 234 mg cocoa flavanols and procyanidins per day (active group) vs. ≤6 mg/day (placebo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of consuming 50 g of raisins (not Flavanols) on cognitive performance, quality of life, and functional activities in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding Flavanols, as the study focused on raisins.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults over 70 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flavanols or caffeine were responsible for inducing hepatic Phase II enzyme activities and inhibiting catalase activity in rats.
results_summary: The study found that neither flavanols nor caffeine were responsible for the induction of hepatic Phase II enzyme activities or the inhibition of catalase activity. Green tea and black tea extracts showed varying effects on enzyme activities, but the results were not consistently dose-dependent.
population_specificity: Rats
effective_dosage: 2.5%, 5.0%, and 7.5% aqueous extracts of green tea; 2.5% aqueous extracts of black tea and decaffeinated black tea

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify flavanol content in beech leaves and assess their antioxidative properties, particularly in response to leaf yellowing and paraquat-induced stress.
results_summary: Yellowing leaves contained over twice the flavanol content of green leaves, with monomeric flavanols (epicatechin and (+)-catechin) comprising up to 80% of the total fraction. (+)-Catechin demonstrated antioxidative properties by preventing paraquat-induced browning in leaf tissues.
population_specificity: Beech leaves from sites with forest decline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cocoa powder and extracts with varying flavanol and procyanidin oligomer content on the growth inhibition of Caco-2 cells.
results_summary: Treatment with procyanidin-enriched (PE) extracts at 50 µg/ml caused 70% growth inhibition in Caco-2 cells, blocking the cell cycle at the G2/M phase. The extracts also significantly reduced key enzyme activities in polyamine biosynthesis, leading to decreased intracellular polyamine levels, suggesting polyamine metabolism as a target for cocoa polyphenols' anti-proliferative effects.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cells (a human colon adenocarcinoma cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of daily walnut supplementation (a rich source of flavanols) on dietary polyphenol intake and urinary excretion in an elderly population.
results_summary: The study found that participants consuming walnuts had significantly higher intake of total polyphenols, flavanols, and other subclasses compared to the control group. There was an inverse association between dietary flavonoid intake and urinary polyphenol excretion, suggesting potential gut elimination pathways.
population_specificity: Free-living elderly individuals
effective_dosage: 15% of daily energy intake from walnuts

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of flavanols and their polymers on metabolic syndrome, focusing on their potential to counteract obesity, hypertension, hyperglycemia, inflammation, and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that flavanols and their polymers effectively counter chronic low inflammation and oxidative stress in metabolic syndrome, with mechanisms linked to their flavonoid structure. The review suggests flavanol dietary supplementation as a potential strategy and highlights albumin's role in flavanol delivery.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome (characterized by obesity, hypertension, and hyperglycemia).
effective_dosage: Efficient doses mentioned but not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cocoa flavanols (CF) improve whole-body insulin-mediated glucose uptake in females with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of CF on insulin-mediated glucose uptake, leaving the efficacy unresolved.
population_specificity: Premenopausal females (19-49 years) with overweight/obesity (BMI 27-35 kg·m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if acute cocoa flavanol intake improves vascular and metabolic responses to an oral nutritional supplement in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The cocoa condition showed significant increases in vascular and metabolic responses compared to placebo, suggesting flavanols may benefit postprandial vascular and glucose/insulin function.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy older adults (50% male, 72 ± 4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how cocoa flavanol (CF) supplementation impacts pulmonary oxygen uptake kinetics during exercise.
results_summary: The study found that acute CF supplementation enhanced oxygen uptake kinetics during moderate-intensity exercise, suggesting improved oxygen delivery. No significant effects were observed during severe-intensity exercise.
population_specificity: 17 participants (11 male, 6 female; mean age 45 ± 6 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of (-)-epicatechin, a flavanol, on mitochondrial function and its potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The review found that (-)-epicatechin supplementation, both acute and chronic, may improve mitochondrial function and induce mitochondrial biogenesis, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for mitochondrial dysfunction-related diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of available data, not a specific study population)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ergogenic potential of flavonoids, particularly their role in exercise performance and immune function.
results_summary: The study found that 37% of included studies reported improved exercise performance with flavonoid supplementation, with anthocyanins showing the highest efficacy (54%). Only two studies linked anthocyanins to anti-inflammatory effects, suggesting potential immune benefits.
population_specificity: 1288 human subjects, both physically untrained and trained.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether monomeric and oligomeric flavanols (MOF) could reduce kidney injuries caused by ibuprofen intake and strenuous exercise in recreational athletes.
results_summary: The study investigated the effects of MOF on kidney injury severity in athletes taking ibuprofen before a half-marathon, but the abstract does not provide specific results regarding MOF's efficacy.
population_specificity: Recreational athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flavanol-rich cocoa could improve body composition and exercise performance in endurance athletes.
results_summary: Cocoa intake significantly reduced body fat percentage, particularly in the trunk, visceral area, and lower limbs, and altered plasma levels of follistatin and leptin, but did not improve athletic performance.
population_specificity: Training endurance athletes
effective_dosage: 5 g of cocoa daily (425 mg of flavanols)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether monomeric and oligomeric flavanols (MOF) could modulate global DNA methylation patterns and influence epigenetic age.
results_summary: The study found that MOF supplementation decreased DNA methylation levels in highly methylated regions, suggesting a potential role in modifying epigenetic patterns. The effects on epigenetic age were dependent on gender and MTHFR genotype.
population_specificity: 13 participants (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: To investigate whether acute cocoa flavanol (CF) supplementation improves cognitive function and hemodynamic responses in patients with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and healthy controls.
results_summary: CF improved reaction time on the flanker test and increased blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) response in specific brain regions in both T1D patients and healthy controls. T1D patients showed no cognitive deterioration but had a smaller BOLD response in certain brain areas compared to controls.
population_specificity: 11 patients with type 1 diabetes and their healthy matched controls.
study_duration: Acute (single dose administered 2 hours before testing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Concord grape juice, containing flavanols, could improve memory function and brain activation in older adults with mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: Participants who consumed grape juice showed reduced semantic interference on memory tasks and increased brain activation in right hemisphere regions, suggesting enhanced neurocognitive function.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the historical and scientific evidence supporting the health benefits of a specific grape seed extract containing flavanols, focusing on its effects on vascular health and inflammatory pathways.
results_summary: The study found that an 8-week supplementation with the grape seed extract led to multiple favorable vascular changes and altered gene expression in inflammatory pathways in leukocytes, suggesting a health benefit in healthy humans. The extract's effects were supported by advanced analytical techniques and historical research.
population_specificity: Healthy humans

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cocoa flavanol intake on exercise performance, recovery, and exercise-induced changes in vascular function, cognitive function, oxidative stress, inflammation, and metabolic parameters.
results_summary: Cocoa flavanol intake reduced exercise-induced oxidative stress, tempered blood pressure increases in obese participants, and altered fat and carbohydrate metabolism during exercise, but did not improve exercise performance in athletes. Chronic intake improved mitochondrial efficiency in untrained participants.
population_specificity: Humans, including athletes and untrained participants, with specific focus on obese individuals for blood pressure effects.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exact amounts mentioned but not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: Acute, sub-chronic (2 weeks), and chronic (3 months) interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of dietary polyphenols, particularly flavanols, to reduce platelet hyperactivity and hypercoagulability, and their complementary anti-platelet therapeutic potential.
results_summary: Flavanols, especially from cocoa and berries, were found to reduce platelet activation and aggregation through multiple pathways, though in vivo data were limited and conflicting. Only flavanols consistently showed efficacy in modulating platelet function both in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of dietary polyphenols and flavanols)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether flavanol-rich lychee fruit extract (FRLFE) supplementation could reduce inflammation and tissue damage in young athletes undergoing intense physical training.
results_summary: FRLFE supplementation significantly reduced interleukin-6 levels during training and increased transforming growth factor-β levels post-training, suggesting potential anti-inflammatory and tissue-protective effects. Some blood parameters, like white blood cell count, were also notably affected by FRLFE.
population_specificity: Twenty healthy male university long-distance runners.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the hypoglycemic properties of flavonoid subcategories and their mechanisms of action in diabetes treatment.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated notable hypoglycemic effects by suppressing carbohydrate metabolism and gluconeogenesis, enhancing glucose uptake and insulin secretion, and reducing insulin resistance, oxidative stress, and inflammation. Certain flavonoids also showed synergistic effects in lowering blood glucose levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies on flavonoids and diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cocoa flavanols could reduce metabolic stress in obese adults with type 2 diabetes following a high-fat fast-food-style meal.
results_summary: Cocoa increased HDL cholesterol and insulin levels but had no significant effects on total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides, glucose, or inflammation markers. It also reduced large artery elasticity without clear overall benefits.
population_specificity: Obese adults with type 2 diabetes (n = 18; 14 women, 4 men; mean age 56 ± 3 years; BMI 35.3 ± 2.0 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 960 mg total polyphenols (480 mg flavanols) in a single beverage dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the latest research on flavonoids, focusing on their antibacterial activity and mechanisms, as well as their synergistic effects with antibiotics.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoids exhibit antibacterial effects on drug-resistant bacteria through multiple mechanisms, including disrupting cell membranes, inhibiting proteins and nucleic acids, and suppressing biofilm formation. Additionally, combining flavonoids with antibiotics (e.g., quercetin with colistin or EGCG with tetracycline) significantly enhanced therapeutic efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research on flavonoids and bacteria).
interactions: Synergistic interactions with antibiotics (e.g., quercetin with colistin, EGCG with tetracycline) were noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of flavonoids in managing non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) by reviewing randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses from the past five years.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated beneficial effects in managing NAFLD by improving lipid metabolism, reducing hepatic steatosis, and providing anti-inflammatory actions. Clinical trials showed significant reductions in liver fat content and improved liver enzyme profiles, though effects on fibrosis were limited.
population_specificity: Individuals with NAFLD, with noted efficacy in subgroups such as older adults and females.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare extraction methods for flavonoids, focusing on Microwave-Assisted Extraction (MAE), and explore their application in treating epilepsy.
results_summary: The study highlights MAE as an efficient and sustainable extraction method for flavonoids, emphasizing their potential in epilepsy treatment due to their free radical-scavenging properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on medicinal plant extraction and therapeutic applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the extraction, separation, content determination methods, chemical constituents, and pharmacological effects of Radix Hedysari flavonoids.
results_summary: The study found that Radix Hedysari flavonoids exhibit multiple pharmacological effects, including cytotoxic effects on tumor cells, antioxidant properties, improvement of osteoporosis, anti-atherosclerosis, anti-fibrotic effects, and immunomodulation. These effects are mediated through various mechanisms such as enzyme regulation, cytokine modulation, and signaling pathway involvement.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad pharmacological review, not limited to a specific population)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the amyloid β (Aβ) aggregation inhibitory activity of flavonoid compounds isolated from eelgrass (Zostera marina) and assess the efficacy of rosmarinic acid treatment in mutant nematodes.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoid compounds with hydroxy substituents showed stronger Aβ aggregation inhibitory activity, which weakened when replaced by methoxy or sulfate groups. Rosmarinic acid treatment was also evaluated for efficacy in mutant nematodes, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Mutant nematodes (specific species not mentioned) and in vitro evaluation of flavonoid compounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of bamboo leaf flavonoids (BLFs) in mitigating Alzheimer's disease progression exacerbated by circadian disruption, focusing on neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, and amyloid-β accumulation.
results_summary: BLFs partially reversed oxidative damage, reduced Aβ deposition, and mitigated inflammation by regulating the Hif3α/Rab7/TNFα/IL1β pathway, demonstrating neuroprotective effects in AD mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6N mice (normal) and APP/PS1 transgenic mice (AD model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the phytochemical basis of Lablab Flos Alba and explore the anti-inflammatory effects of its flavonoid compounds on NLRP3 inflammasome signaling.
results_summary: Twelve new compounds and thirty-two known flavonoids were identified, with nine being new records for the Lablab genus. Compounds 6, 8, and 12 significantly inhibited IL-1β release and demonstrated dual regulatory effects on NLRP3 inflammasome signaling.
population_specificity: Bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs) in an in vitro model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory effects and underlying mechanisms of total flavonoids from Litchi chinensis seeds (TFLS) on breast cancer metastasis.
results_summary: TFLS suppressed breast cancer cell proliferation, migration, and invasion in vitro by reversing the EMT phenotype and inhibited metastasis in vivo, likely through attenuation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR and MAPK signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-468) and in vivo models (zebrafish and mice).
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 44.47 μg/mL and 37.35 μg/mL at 72 h for MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-468 cells, respectively.
study_duration: 72 hours in vitro; duration in vivo not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of UV radiation and fermentation on flavonoid content and other bioactive compounds in caper berries.
results_summary: UV radiation, particularly UV-C, significantly increased flavonoid content, phenolic compounds, and antioxidant activity in caper berries. Fermentation further enhanced these effects, with the highest levels observed after 45 days of fermentation.
population_specificity: Caper berries (Capparis spinosa L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of flavonoids on the NLRP3 inflammasome and their potential as a treatment for diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated strong neuroprotective benefits by inhibiting NLRP3 activation, reducing oxidative stress, and lowering pro-inflammatory cytokines. Preclinical and limited clinical evidence suggests flavonoids may improve nerve function and reduce neuropathic pain in diabetic patients.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with peripheral neuropathy (DPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize how flavonoids enhance cancer immunotherapy by modulating the tumor-immunosuppressive microenvironment and overcoming limitations like poor solubility and bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoids can augment the efficacy of cancer immunotherapy by integrating with modalities like cancer vaccines and immune checkpoint inhibitors, and nanotechnology can help overcome their inherent limitations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on cancer immunotherapy applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of flavonoids from Indonesian medicinal plants as antidiabetic agents by examining their effects on glucose metabolism, insulin sensitivity, and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated potential in managing glucose metabolism, lowering blood sugar levels, and protecting pancreatic β cells from oxidative damage. They also inhibited carbohydrate-digesting enzymes and exhibited antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on antidiabetic potential, no specific human or animal population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the therapeutic mechanisms and drug delivery strategies of flavonoids in spinal cord injury (SCI) and propose future research directions.
results_summary: Flavonoids like quercetin, fisetin, and hesperetin showed anti-inflammatory and anti-apoptotic properties beneficial for SCI recovery, but they face challenges such as poor solubility and low bioavailability. Potential drug delivery strategies, including nanoparticles and hydrogels, were proposed to enhance efficacy.
population_specificity: Spinal cord injury (SCI) patients (preclinical or theoretical focus, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the algicidal potential of Zanthoxylum bungeanum residue extract (rich in flavonoids) and optimize its yield for controlling algal blooms.
results_summary: The study found that Z. bungeanum residue extract significantly inhibited the photosynthetic activity of Tetrodesmus obliquus, reducing Fv/Fm and PIabs values by 24.36% and 88.87%, respectively, at 50 hours. The extract disrupted multiple physiological processes in algal cells, including electron transport and energy distribution in PSII.
population_specificity: Algal cells (Tetrodesmus obliquus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of natural flavonoids (quercetin, isorhamnetin, avicularin, isoquercetin, quercitrin, and taxifolin) for osteoporosis treatment by targeting estrogen receptors (ERs).
results_summary: The study identified 14 gene products linked to osteoporosis, including ESR1 and ESR2, and demonstrated favourable and stable binding of flavonoids to ERα and ERβ, suggesting their potential therapeutic role in osteoporosis.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and computational analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic effects of dietary flavonoids on arthritis, focusing on their mechanisms of action and potential to reduce joint inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoids exhibit potent anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties, reducing joint swelling and arthritis symptoms in preclinical and clinical models, though their bioavailability is limited due to solubility and metabolism issues.
population_specificity: Preclinical and clinical models of arthritis (specific human or animal populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of flavonoids in alleviating oxidative stress and inflammation, common components of many chronic diseases.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated potential to modulate oxidative stress and inflammation by interacting with biological targets, scavenging ROS, and influencing key signaling pathways. Epidemiological studies supported their health benefits, though effects varied based on structural characteristics.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population inferred from chronic disease focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between flavonoid intake and the risk of perimenopausal depression, as well as the mediating role of HDL-c.
results_summary: Higher flavonoid intake was associated with a lower risk of perimenopausal depression and higher serum HDL-c levels, with HDL-c partially mediating this association.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal female participants (n=4603) from the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2005-2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacological effects of Amomum tsaoko flavonoids (ATF) on ulcerative colitis (UC) in mice, focusing on gut microbiota modulation and inflammatory pathways.
results_summary: A high dose of ATF (100 mg/kg) significantly improved UC symptoms, including body weight, colon length, and tissue damage, while reducing serum LPS levels and inhibiting inflammatory pathways. ATF also altered gut microbiota composition, increasing beneficial taxa and decreasing pathogenic genera.
population_specificity: DSS-induced UC mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of flavonoids as modulators of microRNAs (miRNAs) implicated in cardiovascular disease (CVD) pathogenesis, focusing on their cardioprotective properties.
results_summary: The study suggests flavonoids may regulate miRNAs associated with cardiac fibrosis, hypertrophy, and vascular inflammation, offering potential therapeutic benefits for CVD. Preclinical and clinical evidence supports these interactions, though challenges in developing flavonoid-based miRNA therapies remain.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on cardiovascular disease mechanisms)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anticancer mechanisms of Sophora flavescens flavonoids using network pharmacology and molecular simulation techniques to provide a theoretical basis for plant-based anticancer agents.
results_summary: The study identified key anticancer targets (TP53, ESR1, SRC, AKT1, MAPK1) and pathways (PI3K-Akt, RAS/RAF/MEK/ERK) modulated by flavonoids. Molecular docking and dynamics simulations showed strong binding and stability for rutin and luteolin-7-O-gentiobioside, suggesting promising anticancer effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico and network pharmacology study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-Trypanosoma cruzi activity of flavonoids and other compounds isolated from Vernonanthura polyanthes.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoids (luteolin, velutin, and 3-O-methylquercetin) showed activity against trypomastigote forms of T. cruzi, with no toxicity against murine fibroblasts. Homovanillyl alcohol was the most active compound.
population_specificity: Trypomastigote forms of Trypanosoma cruzi and murine fibroblasts.
effective_dosage: EC50 values provided (e.g., homovanillyl alcohol EC50 = 6.3 µg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-atherosclerotic mechanism of polydatin combined with hawthorn flavonoids through gut microbiota and their metabolites.
results_summary: The combination significantly reduced lipid and inflammatory cytokine levels, decreased atherosclerotic lesions, and modulated gut microbiota and TMAO-related pathways in high-fat diet-induced ApoE-/- mice.
population_specificity: ApoE-/- mice fed a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: High dose (polydatin 200 mg/kg daily; hawthorn flavonoids 100 mg/kg daily), medium dose (polydatin 100 mg/kg daily; hawthorn flavonoids 50 mg/kg daily), low dose (polydatin 50 mg/kg daily; hawthorn flavonoids 25 mg/kg daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different flavonoids on the viability and oxidative response of LPS-stimulated macrophages.
results_summary: Flavonoids, particularly EGCG, taxifolin, myricetin, and kaempferol, stimulated macrophage metabolism and reduced NO and ROS levels in the presence of LPS. All tested flavonoids reduced NO levels, while EGCG, myricetin, and kaempferol also reduced ROS levels below untreated control levels.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophages (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 200 to 6.25 µM (cytotoxicity evaluation); 50, 25, and 12.5 µM (oxidative response evaluation)
study_duration: 2 hours (flavonoid treatment), followed by 72 hours (LPS exposure)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze quercetin's molecular mechanisms in cancer therapy and its potential as a therapeutic and immune-modulating agent.
results_summary: Quercetin modulates key cancer-related pathways (PI3K/Akt/mTOR, MAPK/ERK, NF-κB, JAK/STAT), promoting apoptosis, reducing proliferation, enhancing immune recognition, and decreasing tumor inflammation. Nanoformulation strategies improve its bioavailability and targeting.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of molecular and preclinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish an optimal method for extracting flavonoids from tea plant seed husk using ultrasonic-cold isostatic pressure synergistic extraction and evaluate its effects on flavonoid yield and bioactivity.
