results_summary: The study identified optimal extraction conditions (pressure, ethanol concentration, husk amount, and time) and demonstrated that the ultrasonic-cold isostatic pressure method effectively enhanced flavonoid extraction and preserved bioactivity, showing higher antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and bacteriostatic effects compared to other methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Applied pressure 468.440 MPa, 31.169 g tea plant seed husk, ethanol concentration 69.067%, processing time 10.916 min

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the therapeutic effectiveness of TRFD (Total Flavonoids of Rhizoma Drynariae) in inhibiting adipogenesis and promoting osteogenesis in primary osteoporosis via the MAPK/HIF-1α signaling pathway.
results_summary: TRFD significantly improved bone microarchitecture, increased osteogenesis markers (RUNX2, BMP-2), enhanced MAPK and HIF-1α signaling, and promoted osteogenic differentiation while suppressing adipogenic differentiation in BMSCs. The effects were dose-dependent.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with ovariectomy-induced osteoporosis.
effective_dosage: Low and high doses (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the specific compounds in Periploca forrestii Schltr. flavonoids (TFPF) responsible for TNF-α inhibition and elucidate their mechanism of action in rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Quercetin, a compound in TFPF, demonstrated potent anti-TNF-α activity, inhibiting the TNF-α/NF-κB signaling pathway, reducing inflammation, and alleviating RA symptoms in cellular and animal models.
population_specificity: L929 cells, MH7A cells, and Wistar rats (animal model of RA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of hawthorn total flavonoids (HTF) on hyperlipidemia, including its mechanisms of action and impact on liver health and gut microbiota.
results_summary: HTF significantly reduced hyperlipidemia symptoms, improved liver function, and regulated gut microbiota. It also activated lipid metabolism pathways, enhancing lipid consumption and reducing fat accumulation.
population_specificity: High-fat-diet-fed C57BL/6j mice and HepG2 cell models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of total flavonoids from Aronia melanocarpa fruit (AMF) in treating acute lung injury (ALI) and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: The study found that AMF total flavonoids exhibited strong therapeutic efficacy for ALI, reducing inflammatory factors (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α) and regulating inflammatory responses via the PI3K/AKT pathway. UHPLC-MS/MS identified 31 flavonoids, with 11 prototypical compounds and 10 metabolites detected in mouse serum.
population_specificity: LPS-induced ALI model mice
effective_dosage: 107.37 mg g-1 alcoholic extract of total flavonoids

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of flavonoids in treating gastrointestinal (GI) cancers and summarize drug delivery systems to improve their bioavailability.
results_summary: Flavonoids exhibit antioxidant, anti-tumor, and anti-inflammatory activities, with inhibitory effects on various GI cancers. However, their poor water solubility, low permeability, and inferior stability limit absorption efficiency, prompting the exploration of drug delivery systems to enhance bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on GI cancer mechanisms and treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of flavonoid-based bioactive compounds for managing eczema, focusing on their anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anti-allergic properties.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated promise in treating eczema due to their strong anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anti-allergic effects, potentially preventing allergic reactions, inflammation, and skin irritation. The study also highlighted innovative delivery methods like nanoencapsulation and hydrogel-based systems to enhance bioavailability and efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on chronic inflammatory skin conditions like eczema).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-CRC activity of flavonoids and explore the potential of flavonoid-based nanopharmaceuticals for CRC prevention and therapy.
results_summary: Flavonoids show promise in targeting CRC pathogenesis but face challenges like low bioavailability; nanopharmaceuticals may enhance their therapeutic effects and safety. The study highlights recent advances in flavonoid-containing nanocarriers for CRC management.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of nano-delivery systems containing flavonoids to enhance the treatment of acne vulgaris by improving solubility, stability, and bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoid-loaded nanoparticles improved stability, controlled release, and targeted delivery to the skin, enhancing their anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antibacterial properties for acne treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Amomum tsaoko flavonoids (ATFs) on a rotenone-induced Parkinson's disease (PD) mouse model and explore the role of gut microbiota in this effect.
results_summary: ATFs improved motor and constipation symptoms, reduced dopaminergic neuron loss, decreased inflammation-related gene expression, enhanced gut barrier-related gene expression, and reversed gut dysbiosis by reducing pathogenic bacteria and increasing probiotics. These effects suggest ATFs may alleviate PD symptoms via gut microbiota modulation.
population_specificity: Rotenone-induced PD mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the research progress of flavonoids in treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), focusing on their immunomodulatory effects, promotion of ROS production, interaction with miRNA and proteins, and potential to reverse drug resistance.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anticancer properties, showing promise in treating NSCLC alone or in combination with other therapies by inducing apoptosis and reversing drug resistance. Combining flavonoids with anticancer agents, radiotherapy, or nanoparticles enhanced their therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the neuroprotective pathways of flavonoids and evaluate their potential as a long-term treatment for ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Flavonoids show promise in alleviating neuroinflammation and anti-apoptosis, improving long-term outcomes for ischemic stroke patients, though their neuroprotective pharmacodynamics remain unclear.
population_specificity: Ischemic stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how flavonoids (FLA) influence soil microbial communities, soil properties, and the abundance of potential pathogenic fungi.
results_summary: Flavonoids increased the abundance of potential pathogenic fungi in soil, altered microbial community composition, and enhanced soil fertility, pH, and antioxidant enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Soil microbial communities and soil-dwelling pathogenic fungi.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect and mechanism of total flavonoids from Eucommia ulmoides leaves (TFEL) on bone loss in ovariectomized rats and its impact on intestinal flora.
results_summary: TFEL administration increased bone formation markers, decreased bone resorption markers, improved femoral microstructure, and regulated intestinal flora composition in ovariectomized rats without toxic side effects.
population_specificity: 3-month-old female ovariectomized rats
effective_dosage: 50, 100, and 200 mg/kg/d (low, mid, and high doses)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of flavonoids from Ficus carica leaves against UVB radiation and their potential for sunscreen and antioxidant applications.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoids extracted from Ficus carica leaves demonstrated strong antioxidant and UVB protective capabilities, achieving an SPF of 25.6 in sunscreen formulations and protecting zebrafish tail fin from UVB damage. The extracts also reduced E. coli mortality.
population_specificity: Zebrafish and E. coli (no human subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacodynamic basis and mechanism of action of Flemingia philippinensis (FPTF) in treating rheumatoid arthritis (RA) using integrated omics technologies.
results_summary: FPTF significantly alleviated arthritis symptoms in a collagen-induced arthritis model, modulated key signaling pathways (PI3K/AKT and IL-17), restored gut microbiota balance, and reversed metabolic disturbances in RA rats.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanism of TFRD (a flavonoid-rich extract) in treating osteoporosis, focusing on its interaction with gut microbiota and related metabolites.
results_summary: TFRD improved trabecular bone microstructure and density in OVX rats, altered gut microbiota composition (e.g., Akkermansia, Bacteroides), and regulated metabolites and SCFAs, suggesting a potential role in mitigating osteoporosis.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Cassia alata leaf extracts, particularly its flavonoid content, in treating atopic dermatitis by assessing antioxidant, antimicrobial, and wound-healing properties.
results_summary: The study found that the 75% methanol/water extract had high polyphenol content, strong antioxidant and antimicrobial activity against Staphylococcus aureus, and promoted wound healing in human epidermal keratinocyte cells without cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Human epidermal keratinocyte cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 50 μg/mL for wound-healing activity; up to 200 μg/mL tested for cytotoxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory effects of FNB (a flavonoid fraction from Polygonum hydropiper L.) on PCV2-induced inflammatory responses in cell and mouse models.
results_summary: FNB significantly reduced inflammatory factors (MCP-1, IL-6, IL-8, IL-10, TNF-α, ROS, NO) in both RAW264.7 cells and mice post-PCV2 infection, suggesting it modulates the inflammatory response and may enhance host resistance.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 cells and SPF-grade KM mice.
effective_dosage: Various dosages of FNB (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: 12 and 24 hours post-infection in cells; duration in mice not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the chemical constituents and biological activities of flavonoids in E. japonica leaves, focusing on their antioxidant and anti-diabetic effects.
results_summary: The study identified 30 compounds in E. japonica leaves, including flavonoids and phenolics, which demonstrated significant antioxidant and α-glucosidase inhibitory effects. Coumaroyl flavonoid rhamnosides showed excellent anti-diabetic effects, confirmed by molecular docking analysis.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal study implied by molecular docking analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of flavonoids (naringenin, morin, silibinin) and topiramate on glucose metabolic carbon flux in a steatotic liver cell model.
results_summary: Silibinin reduced lipid accumulation and suppressed de novo fatty acid synthesis, while morin enhanced de novo synthesis but suppressed ribose synthesis. Topiramate also reduced lipid accumulation and mitigated de novo synthesis.
population_specificity: HepG2 liver cells with induced steatosis.
effective_dosage: 10 μM for naringenin, morin, silibinin; 44 μM for topiramate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent advances in flavonoids and their synthetic derivatives targeting the estrogen receptor (ER) signaling pathway for ER+ breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: Flavonoids show promising anti-tumor properties and potential in regulating ER signaling, but further in vitro and in vivo studies are needed for clinical translation. The review highlights their mechanisms, structure-activity relationships, and therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Primarily focused on ER+ breast cancer, though specific human or animal populations are not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of UGT706F1 in enhancing heat tolerance in rice through flavonoid metabolism and transcriptional regulation.
results_summary: The study found that UGT706F1 overexpression increased flavonoid and flavonoid glycoside content, improved heat tolerance, and enhanced the transcriptional activity of genes related to flavonoid synthesis and stress response. MYB61 was identified as a transcription factor activating UGT706F1, further boosting heat tolerance and flavonoid glycoside levels.
population_specificity: Rice plants (Oryza sativa)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective effects and mechanisms of Quzhou Aurantii Fructus flavonoids (QAFF) on ulcerative colitis (UC) in mice, focusing on inflammatory responses, gut microbiome modulation, and the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.
results_summary: QAFF effectively reduced colitis symptoms, lowered pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-1β, TNF-α), improved intestinal barrier integrity, and modulated gut microbiota by increasing beneficial bacteria (e.g., Lachnospiraceae_NK4A136_group) and reducing pathogenic bacteria (e.g., Escherichia-Shigella). Metabolomics revealed changes in glycerophospholipid metabolism linked to QAFF's effects.
population_specificity: DSS-induced UC mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of flavonoids as a multi-faceted treatment for Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), focusing on their enzyme-inhibitory actions and the development of flavonoid metal complexes to improve bioavailability.
results_summary: Flavonoids effectively inhibit key enzymes involved in carbohydrate digestion and insulin regulation, such as α-amylase, α-glucosidase, DPP-4, GP, and PTP1B, suggesting a promising approach for T2DM management. However, their clinical application is limited by poor water solubility and bioavailability, which can be improved through metal chelation.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the permeability of flavonoids (baicalein, wogonin, and pinocembrin) through an in vitro inflammatory blood-brain barrier (BBB) model to assess their potential neuroprotective effects.
results_summary: The study found that the permeability and efflux ratios of the three flavonoids significantly increased in the inflammatory BBB model compared to the normal BBB model, suggesting enhanced transport. The flavonoids passed through the BBB via passive diffusion, supporting their potential as neuroprotective agents for CNS diseases.
population_specificity: In vitro model using hCMEC/D3 and HA1800 cells (human cell lines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the noncovalent interaction mechanism between β-lactoglobulin and flavonoids under ultrasound treatment and assess their potential as a novel delivery system for lycopene.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment enhanced the interaction between β-lactoglobulin and flavonoids, primarily through hydrophobic interactions, improving thermal stability, surface hydrophilicity, and antioxidant properties. The β-LG-API complex showed the best ability to deliver lycopene, with superior environmental stability and bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of plant flavonoids in combination with clinical antibiotics against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli to combat antimicrobial resistance.
results_summary: The study found that plant flavonoids combined with antibiotics showed extensive synergistic effects, with 25% of combinations exhibiting synergy against S. aureus and 50% against E. coli, particularly with antibiotics targeting cell membranes or ribosomes. The results suggest flavonoids can enhance antibiotic efficacy.
population_specificity: In vitro study involving bacterial strains (Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli).
interactions: Synergistic interactions with antibiotics affecting cell membranes or ribosomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of natural flavonoids in reducing cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) by protecting intestinal barrier integrity and examining their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that natural flavonoids may protect intestinal barrier function through anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory mechanisms, potentially reducing CVD incidence. Some flavonoids were also docked with ZO-1 targets to identify higher-activity compounds.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on CVDs related to intestinal barrier damage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of natural flavonoids in modulating the Intestinal Mucosal Barrier (IMB) in Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) and their potential for disease prevention and management.
results_summary: The study suggests that natural flavonoids, commonly found in human diets, offer a safe, effective, and non-toxic alternative for promoting intestinal health and preventing IBD by repairing the intestinal mucosal barrier. The findings highlight flavonoids' potential as a therapeutic option for IBD management.
population_specificity: Patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) or those at risk of IMB damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ethosome-encapsulated total flavonoids from Vernonia anthelmintica in enhancing transdermal absorption, antioxidant effects, and melanin production for vitiligo treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the flavonoid ethosome gel demonstrated sustained release, increased melanin production, elevated enzyme activities (TYR, CHE, MAO), and reduced oxidative stress markers (SOD, MDA), indicating therapeutic effectiveness against vitiligo.
population_specificity: Mouse model (hydroquinone-induced vitiligo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the extraction and purification of flavonoids from sour jujube leaves and assess their bioactivity, particularly their effect on ulcerative colitis in mice.
results_summary: The study achieved a high yield of flavonoids (48.47 ± 0.36 mg/g) using optimized ultrasound-assisted extraction, purified them to 74.58 ± 0.63% purity, and demonstrated strong ameliorative effects on DSS-induced ulcerative colitis in mice, reducing inflammation and pathological damage.
population_specificity: Mice with DSS-induced ulcerative colitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified for the in vivo study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of four flavonoids (luteolin, marein, naringenin, and chlorogenic acid) from Coreopsis tinctoria Nutt. on lipid accumulation and oxidative stress in HepG2 cells induced by oleic acid.
results_summary: The study found that the flavonoids improved cell viability, reduced lipid deposition and oxidative stress, and modulated lipid metabolism-related gene expression in OA-treated HepG2 cells. The compounds also enhanced antioxidant activities and decreased reactive oxygen species production.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (human liver cancer cell line) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of Tetrastigma hemsleyanum Diels et Gilg flavonoids (THF) in treating acute hepatic injury (AHI) and identify its active components and pathways.
results_summary: THF, primarily composed of quercetin and kaempferol, reduced liver fibrosis, inflammation, and apoptosis in mice with acute liver injury by modulating the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway and downregulating inflammatory markers (IL-6, TNF-α, CRP) while upregulating IL-10.
population_specificity: Mice with induced acute liver injury (LPS model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of pulsed electric field (PEF) treatment in enhancing the extraction of flavonoids (baicalein, baicalin, wogonin, and wogonoside) from Scutellaria baicalensis roots while maintaining plant viability.
results_summary: PEF treatment successfully increased the leakage of secondary metabolites, achieving optimal results with medium 1 (choline chloride/xylose + 30% water) and two PEF applications. Wogonin concentration matched control levels, and treated plants showed continued growth with a minimum survival rate of 60%, alongside improved root growth parameters and altered phytochemical profiles.
population_specificity: Scutellaria baicalensis Georgi underground organs (roots).
effective_dosage: PEF parameters: E = 0.3 kV/cm, t = 50 µs, N = 33, f = 1 Hz, applied 1-3 times.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flavonoids, alone or in combination with isoquinoline alkaloids, could improve growth performance, anti-inflammatory response, and gut health in broilers under high stocking density and heat stress, as an alternative to antibiotics.
results_summary: Flavonoids, isoquinoline alkaloids, and their combinations reduced stress markers (corticosterone, IL-6, malondialdehyde) and improved gut morphology and microbiome diversity in broilers, with synergistic effects observed in combinations.
population_specificity: Male Ross 308 broiler chicks raised under high stocking density and heat stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of flavonoids in improving metabolic health, particularly their modulation of the AMPK pathway in addressing metabolic syndrome (MetS) and related disorders.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated significant benefits in enhancing glycolipid metabolism, improving glycemic control, inhibiting lipid synthesis, reducing adipogenesis, and attenuating inflammation via AMPK activation. However, excessive concentrations may disrupt metabolic pathways and cause cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (animal or in vitro models) focusing on metabolic syndrome, obesity, and diabetes.

study_goal: To investigate whether vitamin C supplementation with or without flavonoids improves periodontal conditions before and after non-surgical periodontal treatment.
results_summary: Higher plasma vitamin C levels correlated with reduced gingival inflammation, but supplementation (with or without flavonoids) showed no additional benefits. Clustering analysis indicated periodontal severity, not supplementation type, influenced outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontitis referred to the Department of Periodontology at ACTA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on the potential use of selected flavonoids in treating diseases, focusing on their anticancer and antiviral effects, while addressing bioavailability challenges.
results_summary: Flavonoids exhibit antiviral and anticancer properties, with specific compounds like apigenin, luteolin, and quercetin showing documented activity. The relationship between flavonoid intake and cancer risk is non-linear, and they may serve as therapeutic agents in early virus infection stages.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of herbal flavonoids in combating atherosclerosis by examining their mechanisms of action and therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoids may help treat atherosclerosis by regulating lipid metabolism, reducing oxidative stress and inflammation, inhibiting vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation, and modulating autophagy. Various targets, such as ACAT, ACLY, Nrf2, KLF2, NLRP3, and TFEB, were identified as involved in these processes.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of peanut shell flavonoids (PSFs) on the properties of composite films for cherry tomato preservation and their antioxidant capacity.
results_summary: The study found that PSFs enhanced the mechanical and antioxidant properties of the composite films, improving cherry tomato preservation by reducing weight loss, malondialdehyde content, and respiration intensity while maintaining color, appearance, and aroma.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: PeCo-0.5 composite film (specific flavonoid concentration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antileishmanial efficacy and safety of a flavonoid-rich fraction (DCMF) from Fridericia platyphylla encapsulated in zein nanoparticles for potential leishmaniasis treatment.
results_summary: The ZNP-DCMF system demonstrated high antileishmanial activity against Leishmania amazonensis (IC50 of 0.72 μg/mL for amastigotes) with excellent selectivity (SI = 694.44) and no cytotoxicity to macrophages (CC50 > 500 μg/mL). The encapsulated flavonoids remained stable for 49 days, suggesting improved efficacy and reduced toxicity compared to free DCMF.
population_specificity: Leishmania amazonensis promastigotes and amastigotes, and RAW264.7 macrophages (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: IC50 values: 36.33 μg/mL (promastigotes), 0.72 μg/mL (amastigotes); CC50 > 500 μg/mL (macrophages).
study_duration: Stability assessed for 49 days; intervention duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between dietary flavonoids intake and constipation in the adult US population.
results_summary: The study found a negative association between flavonoids intake (including isoflavones, anthocyanidins, flavanones, flavones, flavonols, and total flavonoids) and constipation, with anthocyanidins showing the most stable negative association. An inverted U-shaped relationship was observed for anthocyanidins, with constipation rates decreasing when intake exceeded 0.92 mg.
population_specificity: Adult US population (data from NHANES 2007-2010).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological activities and medicinal potential of prenylated flavonoids (PFs) over the last decade, focusing on their pharmacological effects in the Fabaceae family.
results_summary: The study found that PFs exhibit significant biological activities, including anti-cancer, anti-diabetic, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, anti-Alzheimer's, and neuroprotective effects, highlighting their potential for drug development. The abstract also notes that PFs have been rapidly prepared through isolation and synthesis, underscoring their utility in medicinal chemistry.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research on PFs in plant families, particularly Fabaceae).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal germination conditions for enhancing total flavonoid content in buckwheat sprouts using ultraviolet-B treatment.
results_summary: Ultraviolet-B treatment significantly increased total flavonoid content (1872.84 μg/g fresh weight) and enhanced enzyme activity and gene expression related to flavonoid biosynthesis, though it also caused oxidative damage and inhibited sprout growth. The treatment also boosted antioxidant enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Buckwheat sprouts (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Ultraviolet-B radiation at 30.0 μmol·m-2·s-1 for 7.6 h per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of flavonoids as a plant-based therapeutic intervention for Alzheimer's disease (AD), focusing on their neuroprotective effects and mechanisms.
results_summary: Preclinical studies suggest flavonoids may target AD-related pathogenic factors like oxidative stress, inflammation, and Aβ accumulation, but clinical data remains limited and inconclusive, necessitating further high-quality trials.
population_specificity: Older populations at risk for or suffering from Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic potential of flavonoids, particularly those from traditional Chinese herbal medicines, in treating pancreatic cancer by modulating key biological pathways.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated potent anti-pancreatic cancer properties, including regulation of autophagy, apoptosis, cell growth, and oxidative stress, as well as enhancing chemotherapeutic sensitivity and exerting antiangiogenic and immunomodulatory effects. These bioactive compounds showed promise for both preventive and therapeutic applications in pancreatic cancer.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer patients (primarily discussed in the context of preclinical or theoretical applications, not a specific clinical population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-depression effects of Semen Cuscutae flavonoids (SCFs) in mice subjected to chronic unpredictable mild stress (CUMS) and investigate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: SCFs significantly improved depressive-like behaviors in CUMS mice, increased body weight and food intake, and activated the cAMP-PKA-CREB-BDNF signaling pathway in the hippocampus. High-dose SCFs altered 72 metabolites, with 26 identified as potential biomarkers linked to improved depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: CUMS-induced mice
effective_dosage: High-, medium-, and low-dose SCFs (specific amounts not provided), administered orally once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the potential interaction of bioactive flavonoids with the active site of NUDT5 to assess their viability as inhibitors for breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: Docking analysis revealed that flavonoids like naringin and genistein significantly bind to NUDT5, with genistein showing stronger and more stable interactions, making it a promising inhibitor for breast cancer therapy. Molecular dynamics studies further validated these findings.
population_specificity: In silico (computational) study targeting breast cancer pathways.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Epimedium total flavonoids (EF) for treating primary osteoporosis (POP) through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that EF had comparable efficacy to control treatments, with a statistically significant but clinically modest improvement in lumbar vertebra bone mineral density (BMD). Safety profiles were similar between EF and control groups, with no significant differences in complication rates.
population_specificity: 838 participants with primary osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-diabetic potential of flavonoids, focusing on their mechanisms and clinical translation challenges.
results_summary: Flavonoids exhibit anti-diabetic activity through mechanisms like α-glucosidase inhibition, antioxidant effects, and GLUT4 expression, but their clinical effectiveness is limited by poor biopharmaceutical properties. The review highlights recent advancements in drug delivery systems to address these limitations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of in-vitro, in-vivo, and clinical studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect and molecular mechanism of total flavonoids from Salvia divinorum extract against acetaminophen-induced acute liver injury in mice.
results_summary: The study found that total flavonoids of Salvia divinorum significantly reduced liver injury markers (ALT, AST), improved liver histopathology, reduced iron deposition, and activated the Nrf2/SLC7A11/GPX-4 signaling pathway, suggesting a protective role against acetaminophen-induced liver damage via ferroptosis suppression.
population_specificity: Mice with acetaminophen-induced acute liver injury.
effective_dosage: 100, 200, and 400 mg/kg total flavonoids of Salvia miltiorrhiza; 150 mg/kg bifidus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic effects and molecular mechanisms of Scutellaria baicalensis and its main flavonoids in treating digestive system tumors over the past decade.
results_summary: The study found that S. baicalensis and its flavonoids inhibit tumor cell proliferation, induce autophagy, stimulate immune response, and increase drug sensitivity in digestive system tumors, suggesting their potential as a treatment option.
population_specificity: Digestive system tumors (oral cavity, esophagus, stomach, colon, liver, pancreas)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer properties of isoorientin (ISO), a flavonoid, by reviewing in vitro studies to understand its effects on cell proliferation, apoptosis, and metastasis.
results_summary: ISO demonstrated potential anticancer effects across various cancer types, influencing cell viability, apoptosis, migration, and molecular pathways, though clinical trials were absent.
population_specificity: In vitro studies covering lung, brain, oral, liver, pancreatic, and gastric cancers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular effects and phytochemical composition of Erythroxylum campestre leaf extracts, particularly focusing on its antihypertensive potential.
results_summary: The ECM-ppt-M extract significantly reduced mean arterial pressure, renal vascular resistance, and aortic vascular resistance, especially in hypertensive rats, with phytochemical analysis identifying glycosylated flavonoids as likely contributors to these effects.
population_specificity: Normotensive and spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the combination of delphinidin (DN) and oroxylin A (OA) could inhibit lung cancer cell (A549) development by blocking STAT3 and FAK signaling pathways.
results_summary: The combination of DN and OA induced significant cytotoxicity, ROS generation, mitochondrial membrane potential alteration, nuclear fragmentation, and apoptosis in A549 cells. It also increased G2/M phase cell cycle arrest and suppressed STAT3 and FAK expression, reducing proliferation and promoting pro-apoptotic protein expression.
population_specificity: Lung cancer cells (A549) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dose-response effects, safety, and tolerability of plant flavonoids in cancer treatment and prevention, as well as their pharmacodynamic properties.
results_summary: Flavonoids exhibit a biphasic dose-response, with stimulatory or inhibitory effects depending on dosage, and demonstrate both antioxidant and prooxidant properties that influence redox homeostasis. The study highlights the need to determine optimal dosages for therapeutic efficacy in cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Preclinical cancer models and general patient populations (not specified in detail).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects and mechanism of total water-soluble flavonoids from sweet tea on glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, and liver cell apoptosis in gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) mice.
results_summary: The study found that total water-soluble flavonoids improved glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity in GDM mice, reduced liver cell apoptosis, and acted through multiple targets and signaling pathways, primarily involving quercetin and luteolin.
population_specificity: GDM mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the extraction and purification processes of total flavonoids from Lycopi herba roots (TFLHR) and evaluate their anti-proliferative effects on human fibroblast-like synoviocytes (HFLS-RA) in the context of rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The study successfully optimized extraction conditions, achieving a high flavonoid content (90.484 ± 0.974 mg/g) and purification (63.9 ± 1.86% purity). Purified TFLHR demonstrated significant concentration-dependent anti-proliferative effects on HFLS-RA cells, suggesting potential therapeutic value for rheumatoid arthritis.
population_specificity: Human fibroblast-like synoviocytes (HFLS-RA), key pathological cells in rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of FRN (Flavonoids from Rhododendron nivale Hook. f.) in alleviating alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) and to elucidate its underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: FRN treatment significantly reduced hepatic lipid accumulation and restored serum AST and ALT levels in ALD mice. It upregulated PPARα expression, downregulated ACSL1, and reduced long-chain fatty acid accumulation, with its protective effects mediated through PPARα signaling.
population_specificity: Murine model of ALD and in vitro cellular models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of flavonoids (Quercetin, Fisetin, Rutin, and Myricitrin) to disrupt YBX1 protein-protein interactions (PPIs) and their effects on YBX1-driven cancers.
results_summary: Quercetin and Fisetin downregulated YBX1 expression in MCF-7 cells in a dose-dependent manner (50–150 μM) and showed favorable drug-likeness in ADMET analysis, while Rutin and Myricitrin were less effective. The study suggests flavonoids may disrupt YBX1 PPIs, offering a novel therapeutic strategy.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of flavonoids as therapeutic agents for obesity by examining their role in improving metabolic complications and modulating adipokine and batokine release.
results_summary: The study found that flavonoids may help ameliorate obesity-related metabolic issues, including adipose tissue dysfunction, inflammation, insulin resistance, hepatic steatosis, and cardiovascular comorbidities, partly by influencing adipokine and batokine secretion. However, the mechanisms of action remain insufficiently understood to formulate definitive therapeutic theories.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on obesity-related metabolic complications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the neuroprotective properties of flavonoids in neurodegenerative diseases by examining their effects on cellular stress and neuronal survival.
results_summary: Flavonoids demonstrated potential neuroprotective effects by modulating key signaling pathways (Nrf2/ARE, MAPK, PI3K/Akt), reducing cellular stress, and improving neuronal survival, though clinical implementation challenges remain.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on neurodegenerative diseases)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of flavonoids for treating liver diseases, focusing on clinical outcomes and molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study summarized recent progress on the hepatoprotective effects of flavonoids, highlighting their role in addressing oxidative stress, inflammation, and dysregulated energy metabolism in liver diseases. It also outlined underlying molecular signaling pathways but noted the need for further pharmacology and toxicology research.
population_specificity: Not specified (general liver disease context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of flavonoids from four medicinal flowers in preventing and treating liver and eye diseases.
results_summary: The study identified 125 flavonoids in the four medicinal flowers, which showed potential in maintaining liver and eye homeostasis by regulating oxidative stress, inflammation, and other pathological mechanisms. These flavonoids exhibited antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antiviral, and antifibrotic properties, supporting their traditional use for "clearing the liver and improving vision."
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or in vivo studies inferred from mechanisms discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects and molecular mechanisms of flavonoids from staple grains and legumes on lipid metabolism, as well as potential improvements for their application in anti-obesity dietary supplements or drugs.
results_summary: Flavonoids were found to intervene in lipid metabolism by inhibiting lipogenesis, promoting lipolysis, enhancing energy metabolism, reducing appetite, suppressing inflammation, enhancing insulin sensitivity, and improving gut microbial composition. Fermentation and sprouting techniques enhanced flavonoid content and these beneficial effects, primarily through regulating the AMPK signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human lipid metabolism)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of IgG antibodies against tTG and DGP in IgA-deficient adults with confirmed or suspected celiac disease and relate these findings to adherence to a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that IgG anti-tTG was a more reliable marker for celiac disease in IgA-deficient adults compared to anti-DGP, which had lower diagnostic specificity. High levels of these antibodies were frequently observed despite adherence to a gluten-free diet.
population_specificity: IgA-deficient adults with confirmed or suspected celiac disease, including a control group of IgA-deficient blood donors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to translate and validate the Spanish version of the Celiac Disease Quality Of Life Survey (CD-QOL) to measure HRQOL in celiac patients, including those on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The translated CD-QOL showed high internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.90), excellent feasibility (99.2% completion rate), and significant correlations with EuroQol and D-FIS. The CD-QOL scores varied based on self-reported health status (good, fair, or poor).
population_specificity: 298 celiac patients (201 on a gluten-free diet and 97 at diagnosis).

study_goal: The researchers were examining the association between neuromyelitis optica and dermatitis herpetiformis in a patient with celiac disease managed by a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that the patient's celiac disease was managed with a gluten-free diet, but it did not assess the diet's efficacy or safety in treating or preventing neuromyelitis optica or dermatitis herpetiformis.
population_specificity: A 53-year-old woman with celiac disease and neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet could improve symptoms in patients with fibromyalgia who did not have celiac disease but showed gluten sensitivity.
results_summary: The study found that 20 patients with fibromyalgia and non-celiac gluten sensitivity experienced symptom improvement, including remission of pain, return to normal life, or discontinuation of opioids, after adopting a gluten-free diet. The mean follow-up period was 16 months.
population_specificity: 20 patients with fibromyalgia and non-celiac gluten sensitivity (negative for celiac disease via anti-transglutaminase assay and duodenal biopsy).
